title: How to Store Chocolate

steps.headline: Place the chocolate in an airtight bag or container.
steps.description: Use a plastic zipper bag and squeeze as much of the air out of the bag as you can. This will prevent the chocolate from absorbing any odors from spices or other nearby items. As an alternative, you can use plastic wrap. Just be sure to wrap it as tightly as you can and use at least 2 layers (1 across the chocolate width-wise and 1 across the chocolate lengthwise) so there are no air holes.

steps.headline: Keep chocolate in a dry environment that’s 60°F to 70°F (16°C to 21°C).
steps.description: Storing chocolate in a cool, dry climate will keep the cocoa butter stable, preventing it from melting and keeping the sugars from moving around. This is important to ensure you get the same sweet flavor in every bite. A spice cabinet, pantry, or drawer located away from the stove and oven is the perfect place. It’s okay (but not ideal) to keep your chocolate at room temperature if you keep your home around 70°F to 75°F (21°C to 24°C). If your home gets hotter than 75°F (24°C), you may need to store your chocolate in the refrigerator or freezer.

steps.headline: Put the wrapped chocolate in a dark place away from natural or artificial light.
steps.description: Exposing chocolate to light can cause melting and affect the texture and flavor of the chocolate. Place the airtight bag of chocolate in a spice cabinet, cupboard, or drawer to shield it from light exposure. This is especially important for cream-filled truffles and cream-based varieties like milk chocolate and white chocolate.

steps.headline: Avoid putting your chocolate in the refrigerator if you can.
steps.description: The cocoa butter in chocolate can absorb odors from other items in your fridge like cheese, meats, or cooked dishes. Refrigerators are also very humid and that moisture can cause the sugars to redistribute, causing condensation to form on the surface of the chocolate, which changes its texture. However, if the chocolate has a creamy filling (like truffles or specialty chocolate bars), it's best to refrigerate it to prevent the filling from going bad. If you do end up putting chocolate truffles or cream-filled bars into the refrigerator, let it come to room temperature before you unwrap it. This will prevent "sugar bloom," which is when surface-level condensation dissolves some of the sugars and recrystallizes, resulting in a white coating and grainy texture.

steps.headline: Refrigerate your chocolate during hot summer months, if necessary.
steps.description:
If you live in a relatively hot area and don't have air conditioning, it's better to put chocolate in the refrigerator. Be sure to wrap it in tin foil or plastic wrap and then seal it in an airtight container or bag. Squeeze out as much of the air from the bag as possible. When you're ready to eat it, remove the package from the refrigerator and let it come to room temperature before you unwrap it to prevent oxidation and “sweating.”
Open chocolate bars and truffles refrigerated in an airtight container will stay fresh up to 6 months. Temperatures over 75°F (24°C) can melt the chocolate and spoil the coating on melted and re-hardened chocolate (which is used on most chocolate bars). Wrap the bag or container in a dish towel to provide extra insulation, keeping the risk of condensation as low as possible.

steps.headline: Freeze chocolate only after refrigerating it for 24 hours for long-term storage.
steps.description: Chocolate that is refrigerated for 24 hours and then frozen will retain its flavor and texture for 6 months to 1 year. Place the chocolate bar into an airtight container, squeeze out as much of the air as possible to prevent freezer burn, and place it in the refrigerator for 1 day. Then, move the sealed bag to the freezer. Stored in this way, chocolate bars and truffles will stay fresh for 6 months to 1 year. Refrigerating it first will prevent temperature shock, preserving its texture and flavor.

steps.headline: Transfer chocolate from the freezer to the refrigerator 24 hours before eating.
steps.description: Quick temperature changes can affect the taste and texture of the chocolate, so it’s important to let it come to room temperature slowly. Remove the sealed container of chocolate from the freezer and place it in the refrigerator for 24 hours. Then, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes to 1 hour before opening the package and eating it. Chilled chocolate won't melt on your tongue the same way that room temperature chocolate will, which means its flavor and texture won't be as the chocolatier intended.

steps.headline: Keep the cocoa powder in its original container if you can.
steps.description: The container that the cocoa powder came in is designed to be airtight, so keep it in the original packaging if you can. If the original container is cracked or gets wet, transfer the cocoa powder into another airtight container or a plastic bag. If you’re using a plastic bag, squeeze out as much of the air as possible before you seal it.

steps.headline: Store the container in an environment that’s 60°F to 70°F (16°C to 21°C).
steps.description: Storing the cocoa powder in a place that’s 60°F to 70°F (16°C to 21°C) will prevent flavor loss over time. Too much heat or cold can cause the cocoa powder to lose its aroma and flavor. Unopened cocoa powder will last for 2 to 3 years while opened cocoa powder will last for 1 year. Avoid putting cocoa powder in the refrigerator or freezer because the humidity will cause the powder to lose its bittersweet taste and powdery texture sooner. A dry, powdery texture is necessary if you intend to bake cookies, brownies, or sweetbreads with the cocoa powder.

steps.headline: Place sealed cocoa powder in a cabinet away from light, moisture, and heat.
steps.description: Cocoa powder needs to stay as dry as possible, so don’t put it in a cabinet or on a shelf near the stove, oven, sink, or anywhere that emits heat and moisture. Store it in the pantry or in a dark cupboard to preserve its pungent, bittersweet flavor as long as possible. Both unsweetened and sweetened varieties need to be stored in this manner.
